description: Borrowed from French burlesque, from Italian burlesco (“parodic”).

adjectives.description: burlesque (comparative more burlesque, superlative most burlesque)

examples: It is a dispute among the critics, whether burlesque poetry runs best in heroic verse, like that of the Dispensary, or in doggerel, like that of Hudibras.

entries.meaning: A derisive art form that mocks by imitation; a parody.
A variety adult entertainment show, usually including titillation such as striptease, most common from the 1880s to the 1930s.
A ludicrous imitation; a caricature; a travesty; a gross perversion.

verbs.description: burlesque (third-person singular simple present burlesques, present participle burlesquing, simple past and past participle burlesqued)

entries.meaning: To make a burlesque parody of.
To ridicule, or to make ludicrous by grotesque representation in action or in language.
examples: They burlesqued the prophet Jeremiah's words, and turned the expression he used into ridicule.
